columns.text: In this question, we will use the concept of accounting break-even to solve for the cashflow as well as the different quantities required to reach the specific goals of the company.

**a.** We can recall that at the accounting break even, the net income is exactly zero. 

In order to solve this problem, since the fixed cost and depreciation are not indicated, we can simplify the formula by simply dividing the initial cost by the number of planes. We can do this since the value we will get will equal the amount that each plane needs to generate in order to get the return on the investment.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cashflow per plane}&=\dfrac{\$13,000,000,000}{249}\\[15 pt]
&=\$52,208,835.34
\end{aligned}$$

This means that in order to achieve accounting break-even, each plane should be valued at $\$52,208,835.34$

**b.** For this, we first need to solve for the value for the return on investment. To do this, we can simply take the $20\%$ of $13$ billion.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return}&=\$13,000,000,000 \times 0.20\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,600,000,000
\end{aligned}$$

The expected return is $\$2.6$ billion.

Using the same concept in Step 1, we can use this formula to solve the problem:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cashflow per plane}&=\dfrac{\$2,600,000,000}{\text{number of planes}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Since we already know the cashflow per plane, we can get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of planes}&=\dfrac{\$2,600,000,000}{\$52,208,835.34}\\[15pt]
&=49.8\\[15 pt]
&\approx 50
\end{aligned}$$

In order for them to make a $20\%$ return on the investment, they need to sell $50$ planes.

**c.** For this, since there is already a specific time frame and a rate of return, we need to use an annuity table. Check an annuity table to get the annuity factor for $10$ years with $20\%$ rate and you will get: $4.1925$ . Divide the initial investment by this value to get the expected return:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return}&=\dfrac{\$13,000,000,000}{4.1925}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,100,775,194
\end{aligned}$$

The expected return is $\$3,100,775,194$

Using the same formula in Step 3, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of planes}&=\dfrac{\$3,100,775,194}{\$52,208,835.34}\\[15 pt]
&=59.39\\[15 pt]
&\approx 60
\end{aligned}$$

In order to fulfill this return on investment, they need to sell $60$ planes per year for the next $10$ years.
